message:
Chrome is trying to hide URLs. I don't like it.
http://www.allenpike.com/2014/burying-the-url/
name: Burying the URL - Allen Pike
caption: www.allenpike.com
description: Of course it still supports them, but the time where users actually see URLs is ending. With Chrome’s “Enable origin chip in Omnibox” flag, Location becomes a write-only field. Clicking there no longer reveals the URL for the user to edit or share, but instead waits for you to search Google.

data.message:
I can see the benefit for normal users, even though taking away "read" view is a bit of sacrifice even for normal users.
But for web developers, this is just silly :(
But isn't that bad for security even for normal users? What with phishing scams and all.

I had similar thoughts. Note the domain is still shown at the very left. Hiding other parts like sub-domain and path etc should in fact reduce phishing attack, as explained by example URL in the post.
لو عملوها هبعتلهم رسالة أشتمهم فيها ، بكل وضوح يعني :D

أنا شفت براوزر بيعمل الحركة دي قبل كدا، بيخفي العنوان كله ويسيب الدومين، غالبا كان أوبرا أو سفاري. عموما شكلها كدا قريب بما إن البراوزرات في طريقها لأن تصبح IDEs بالنسبة للمبرمجين و Operating Systems بالنسبة للمستخدمين فشكلهم هيعملوا نسختين من كل براوزر، Developer Edition و البني-آدم-العادي-رجل-الشارع-إيدشن حتى تصبح إصدارة المستخدم العادي سريعة لأقصى حد بدون أي إضافات للمبرمجين وكمان علشان مايبقاش فيها consoles والخ من تلك الأدوات الأمر الذي سيساعد على توقف هراء "غيّر لون بروفايلك" وما شابه ومش هيبقى للفيسبوك حجه إنه يمنع الكونسول ساعتها بقى!

I think they made this move to increase web security, but this also will stagnant the work of spreading the information ... this of course will favor Social platforms like Facebook & Twitter. Likes & Tweets will be the main way for spreading information inside web. Monopoly at the end, very bad news!
Not sure saying "of course will favor Social platforms like Facebook & Twitter." in a comment about Google (all competitors in some areas) can be called a monopoly!

Taking away sub-domain/path is not new in modern browsers, although it's usually done by fading the irrelevant parts away using light gray color and only focusing the primary domain in black.
The trend we see is improving the dev tools in standard user browsers. This is the first incident of a change being good for users and bad for developers

I can't seem to make much out of that

> but this also will stagnant the work of spreading the information ... this 
> of course will favor Social platforms like Facebook & Twitter. Likes & 
> Tweets will be the main way for spreading information inside web.

What's the correlation between spreading information and burying the URL in the browser? That, and what's it got to do with "Likes & Tweets" being the main way of spreading information -which is absurd to put it lightly- ?

@Hady Ahmed: My dad used to call me regularly to ask me how to send an article he's reading right now to a friend, he's not aware of the concept of URLs, he just knows "the .com thing" (the domain) and that's it, tech-illiterate people actually share stuff exclusively using these share buttons, my mum once sent a YouTube video to someone using the e-mail option in YouTube's share section (not sure if it's still there), something that I didn't know existed!
So sadly, it's not as absurd as you think it is :\

Sure Google not considering that move to favor Fb or Twtr dominance, it may think to shake G+ a lil' bit ... but I'm talking about my expectations of what may happen, if URL hiding adopted by IE, FF & Chr ... then this move will favor Social platforms

Hassan Aly Selim It is absurd however, since we're not discussing an experience. We're discussing a technical implementation. URLs whether they're exposed or not will continue to be the only means of information sharing on the web. Unless the web conceptually changes its underpinned ideologies.
Saying burying the URL will slow down information sharing is IMO an unfounded claim, your "Like" eventually translates to a link being shared. Which can still be copied/pasted, stored or shared again.
Same goes for tweets. So it's irrelevant that my mother can't still visit a website she doesn't have a bookmark for.

About correlation ... URL means reader (normal reader) knows the path and source of the information .. hiding it means users will see layers and layers of loops (maybe ..), this will not affect only developers, but also the whole web information ecosystem, bloggers, journalists , web activists ... etc
